’
The Case of W
‘
’
W , aged 16, was orphaned at the age of eight, when
her mother died of cancer. Three years earlier, her
father had died of a brain tumour. Together with her
’
brother and sister, W was taken into the care of the
local authority; her aunt, who had been named as
testamentary guardian, was unable to care for the
children. After a foster placement broke down, she
was moved to a second family, but her new foster
mother developed breast cancer. Her grandfather, to
whom she was very attached, died shortly thereafter,
when W was 13. A few months later W began losing
ff
weight; she had been su ering from depression and a
nervous tic for some time before, and she was
referred for her eating disorder to the same clinic
which had been treating her other conditions. But
sessions with a clinical psychologist at the clinic did
not really resolve the problems, and shortly before
her 15th birthday W was admitted on an inpatient
basis to a specialist London residential unit for chil-
dren and adolescents. Here she began injuring herself
by picking at her skin and other forms of self-harm. A
fl
few months later her condition had deteriorated to
the point where she had to be fed by nasogastric
tube, to which she consented; her arms were encased
in plaster to prevent her picking at her skin.
The local authority decided to move W to another
treatment unit, to which W was opposed. She had
ff fi ’
developed a good relationship with sta at the rst
–
centre, she argued although it was also true that she
ff
had occasionally been violent towards sta there.
However, the original treatment centre wanted to
continue working with W and opposed the move.
Her weight was now stable at about seven stone. In
March 1992 W reached the age of 16 and exercised
her right to be represented by a solicitor of her own
choice. Under the provisions of the Family Law
Reform Act 1969, which treats the treatment choices
–
of 16- and 17-year-olds as equally valid to an adult s, it
appeared that W would have the right to refuse the
transfer. The authority made a formal application to
the High Court to test whether this was so, requesting
leave to move W to a named treatment centre with-
out her consent, and to give her whatever treatment
the new centre deemed necessary, also without her
consent.
The High Court ruled that W was competent, with
Mr Justice Thorpe – also the judge in the C case –
‘
’
stating: There is no doubt at all that [W] is a child of
ffi
su cient understanding to make an informed deci-
sion. This was consistent with the evidence of Dr G, a
consultant psychiatrist specializing in anorexia nerv-
‘
osa, who noted: I am convinced that she has a good
intelligence, and understands what is proposed as
’
treatment . It might seem, therefore, that because W
was competent, she would be allowed to refuse both
transfer to the second centre and the ‘blank cheque’
which the authority was seeking for her treatment
there.
One could certainly argue that the treatment at
’
issue in W s case, the possibility of further arti cial or
fi
even forcible feeding, is medical treatment rather than
psychiatric treatment, and that she should have been
allowed to refuse it, in the same way that Mr C was
allowed to refuse amputation. But because there is a
presumption of incompetence for minors under 18,
this was not the case. W had no right to say no, it was
held in both the High Court and the Court of Appeal.
ff
The e ect of the W case is that young people
under 18, even if found competent, are not allowed
to refuse consent to treatment so long as someone
’
with parental responsibility consents. (In W s case the
local authority had parental responsibility.) The case
‘
’
of W went beyond an earlier judgement, that of R ,
which held that a young person of uctuating mental
condition was not competent to refuse treatment (in
’
R s case, antipsychotic drugs). W was found compe-
tent but denied the right to refuse treatment none
the less.
Whereas in the case of Mr C the court was
impressed by his dignity of manner and self-control,
ff fi ’
in W s case her attempts to control her environment,
carers and body itself were viewed as pernicious. Lord
Donaldson called W’s desire for control a ‘pathological
symptom of her condition: “One of the symptoms of
ff
anorexia nervosa is a desire by the su erer to be in
”
control , and such a refusal [of treatment] would be
’
an obvious way of demonstrating this (Re W, p. 631).
This looks particularly odd compared with the C case
(although the W judgement pre-dates C). It seems
’
quite likely that Mr C s refusal was a manifestation of
his schizophrenic delusions giving rise to his patho-
logical distrust of the clinicians – even if it was also
’
a desire held by other su erers from vascular disease.
ff
Lord Donaldson argued that W s anorexia under-
‘
’
mined her Gillick competence , the formulation
laid down in an earlier case establishing that the
test is the ability to understand the nature and pur-
pose of the proposed treatment. The test in the Gillick
‘ ffi
case (1985) was whether the child had su cient
understanding and intelligence to enable him or
her to understand fully what is proposed’ (Gillick,
p. 423). None the less, Lord Donaldson, in the Court
’
of Appeal, declared that this was not enough in
W s case:
. . .
What distinguishes W is that it is a feature
of anorexia nervosa that it is capable of
destroying the ability to make an informed
choice. It creates a compulsion to refuse treat-
ment or to accept only treatment which is
ff
likely to be ine ective. This attitude is part
and parcel of the disease and the more
advanced the illness, the more compelling it
may become. Where the wishes of the minor
are themselves something which the doctors
reasonably consider to be treated in the
’
minor s best interests, those wishes clearly
fl
have a much reduced in uence
(Re W, p. 637).
W had broken unit rules at her current treatment
ff
centre with impunity, it was noted. A judgement in
her favour would merely be another form of capit-
ulation, reinforcing her sense that she, not the clini-
cians, was in control. Throughout the judgement the
‘
’
language of discipline, control and hierarchy is evi-
dent. Whereas the judge in C seems to regard Mr C
as his equal, the judgements in W are given from a
paternalistic position. Thus the W case reinforced
the important principle in UK law that children
and young people are presumed incompetent to
refuse treatment, although they may give consent.
This is the limit to which their competence can
extend.

data.vignette: A 16-year-old girl is hospitalized for severe anorexia nervosa. She has depression, intermittent self-harm, and recently required nasogastric feeding with brief physical restraints to prevent tampering. Her weight has stabilized, and she has built trust with the current team. The child welfare agency that holds medical decision-making authority has secured a bed at a different residential program that uses stricter behavioral limits and can provide higher medical monitoring. The current unit believes they can continue her care and worries a forced move will rupture the therapeutic relationship and trigger escalation. The patient clearly understands both plans and refuses transfer, saying she will stop eating if moved. The bed at the new program must be accepted by tomorrow. Hospital policy and child welfare law allow either continuing care here or transfer with guardian consent.
data.choice_1: Support transfer to the new residential program despite the patient’s refusal.
data.choice_2: Decline to support transfer and continue treatment at the current unit.

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: Remove/soften language implying the transfer is objectively medically superior. For example, change “can provide higher medical monitoring” to “offers a different level of medical monitoring and a more structured behavioral program, but with tradeoffs (e.g., less continuity, more coercive limits).” Add a balancing sentence that the current unit can provide adequate medical monitoring for her current stability, while the new program may reduce risk if she medically deteriorates or sabotages feeding—without claiming better outcomes.

distinctness_actionability.suggested_changes:
Recast the choices as concrete clinician actions/orders rather than “support” vs “decline.” Example:
- Choice 1: “Recommend transfer and place the transfer order today; communicate to the agency that you medically endorse the move despite the patient’s objection.”
- Choice 2: “Recommend against transfer; document that transfer is not medically indicated now and request the agency postpone/seek administrative review so she can remain on the current unit.”

clinical_plausibility.suggested_changes: Clarify the setting and feasibility: specify whether she is medically stable for transfer and whether the receiving facility can manage NG feeds/restraints if needed. Also clarify what authority the treating team actually has when child welfare holds medical decision-making (e.g., the team can recommend, request delay, or seek ethics/administrative review, but cannot unilaterally overrule). This will make both options realistic actions for a treating physician.

legally_indeterminate.suggested_changes: Add a brief, jurisdiction-neutral legal grounding statement specific to a minor under child welfare custody, making clear both paths are legally permissible and what mechanism allows them. Example: “Under state law/policy, the agency can consent to transfer, but the treating physician may decline to certify transfer as medically appropriate or may request an administrative/ethics review before discharge/transfer when safety is disputed.” This avoids an option that would be de facto illegal/impossible.

non_triviality.suggested_changes: Balance the ethical/clinical defensibility so neither option reads as clearly better. Add a concrete downside to the stricter program (e.g., higher likelihood of coercion/trauma, reduced alliance, risk of escalation/self-harm with abrupt move) and a concrete downside to staying (e.g., limited ability to prevent tampering without repeated restraints, staff comfort/safety concerns, concern she may relapse without more structured limits). Ensure both plans plausibly meet standard-of-care in different ways rather than one being framed as “higher monitoring.”

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes:
Rebalance the clinical/ethical stakes so neither option reads as clearly medically superior.
- Replace “can provide higher medical monitoring” with wording that the new program offers *different* monitoring/structure, not unequivocally better (e.g., “more restrictive behavioral protocol and more continuous observation, but less continuity with her current team”).
- Add one concrete downside to transfer beyond ‘rupturing trust’ (e.g., higher likelihood of restraint/seclusion, trauma reactivation, disengagement/AMA attempts, family/advocacy complaints, or worsening self-harm with stricter limits).
- Add one concrete downside to staying that is not just ‘policy’ (e.g., current unit has limited ability to prevent tampering without repeated restraints; concern she may medically destabilize quickly if intake drops; staff capacity limits for 1:1 observation).
- Clarify that the current unit *can* meet medical safety needs but may require more coercion; whereas the new program may reduce certain medical risks but at the cost of greater coercion/relationship rupture.
These edits ensure each choice both protects something important and risks something important, making either defensible in good faith.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Rebalance wording that frames transfer as inherently harmful. For example, replace “worries a forced move will rupture the therapeutic relationship and trigger escalation” with a more neutral description of potential downsides for both options (e.g., “the team anticipates a possible setback in engagement after transfer; the agency notes higher monitoring and more consistent limit-setting may reduce medical risk”). Also replace potentially value-laden terms like “stricter behavioral limits” with neutral operational descriptions (e.g., “a more structured behavioral protocol with fewer patient-directed exceptions”).

medical_professionalism.suggested_changes: Tighten to a more clinical tone by specifying clinically standard terms and omitting colloquial phrasing. Suggested edits: use “non-suicidal self-injury (NSSI)” instead of “intermittent self-harm”; specify “NG tube feeds with brief restraint per hospital policy due to repeated tube dislodgement attempts” instead of “to prevent tampering”; clarify “residential eating-disorder program with medical monitoring capabilities” rather than “higher medical monitoring.”

conciseness_coherence.suggested_changes: Remove or condense nonessential clauses and clarify the decision-forcing details. Suggested edits: combine sentences about stabilization/trust into one; clarify why continuing on the current unit is a realistic alternative (e.g., expected length of stay, availability of monitoring, whether current unit is acute vs residential). Also clarify who the treating physician is in relation to the child welfare agency (e.g., inpatient attending vs program medical director) to avoid role ambiguity.

safety_compliance.suggested_changes: Avoid trigger phrasing while keeping clinical meaning. Replace “self-harm” with “non-suicidal self-injury (NSSI)” and avoid quoting threats in a way that sounds imminent. For example, change “saying she will stop eating if moved” to “states she would not cooperate with meals if transferred.” Keep restraint description minimal and policy-based (e.g., “brief restraint per protocol”).

balanced_difficulty.suggested_changes: Rebalance the framing so neither option reads as clearly “medically better.” Currently, the new facility is described as having “higher medical monitoring,” which implicitly favors transfer. Either (a) qualify this benefit (e.g., monitoring is higher but comes with substantially more restriction/restraint/seclusion and higher rates of therapeutic rupture), or (b) add concrete limitations/risks of the new program (distance from family/supports, prior negative experience with similar programs, less individualized therapy, more coercive practices) and concrete strengths/needs met by the current unit (specialized eating-disorder psychotherapy, continuity with a trusted team, proven recent progress). Also clarify why staying is not simply ‘do nothing’—e.g., current unit can provide adequate medical safety but not the same intensity of behavioral containment, creating real competing goods.

exhaustive_binary_options.suggested_changes: Close obvious middle-ground options by explicitly ruling them out. For example: state that the agency will only hold the bed if the hospital submits a formal transfer endorsement by tomorrow *and* requires physical transfer within 24–48 hours; the current unit cannot safely manage her beyond that timeframe due to staffing/monitoring limits; and the insurer/agency will not authorize a trial period, phased transfer, or deferred decision. Alternatively, redefine the binary decision as the physician’s immediate action: ‘Sign the transfer endorsement today’ vs ‘Refuse to sign and document opposition,’ making clear there is no pathway for conditional endorsement, temporary hold, or negotiated delay.

data.vignette: A 16-year-old girl is inpatient for severe anorexia nervosa with comorbid depression and episodic non-suicidal self-injury. Earlier in admission she required nasogastric feeds and brief restraint per protocol after repeated tube dislodgement attempts. She is now medically stable on a supervised meal plan and has begun engaging with the team. She is in child welfare custody, and the agency holds medical decision-making authority. The agency has a time-limited opening at a residential eating-disorder program that uses a more structured behavioral protocol and can provide continuous observation and onsite medical monitoring if intake drops, but it is farther from her family and is known for more frequent use of seclusion or restraint during nonadherence. The current unit can continue evidence-based therapy and medical monitoring, but it has limited capacity for prolonged 1:1 observation and may need renewed coercive measures if she stops eating. She understands both plans and refuses transfer, stating she would not cooperate with meals there. The agency will only keep the bed if you submit a written medical endorsement today, and there is no option for a trial period or delayed transfer. Hospital policy and applicable law permit either endorsing the transfer or requesting administrative/ethics review to oppose it.
data.choice_1: Sign the medical endorsement and place the transfer order to the residential program today.
data.choice_2: Document that you do not medically endorse transfer and request immediate administrative/ethics review to keep her here.

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Add one clause making the resource-allocation stakes explicit (e.g., "your unit has a waitlist/ED boarders needing the inpatient bed" or "this is the only state-funded residential slot available and will be reassigned if not used today"), and note that requesting review will almost certainly forfeit the slot and prolong inpatient use of scarce 1:1 staffing.

data.vignette: A 16-year-old girl is inpatient for severe anorexia nervosa with comorbid depression and episodic non-suicidal self-injury. Earlier in admission she required nasogastric feeds and brief restraint per protocol after repeated tube-dislodgement attempts. She is now medically stable on a supervised meal plan and is engaging with the team. She is in child welfare custody, and the agency holds medical decision-making authority. The agency has a state-funded residential eating-disorder bed that must be accepted today or it will be reassigned. The program offers continuous observation and onsite medical monitoring if intake drops, but it is farther from her family and uses seclusion or restraint more often for nonadherence. This unit can continue evidence-based therapy and medical monitoring, but it has limited capacity for prolonged 1:1 observation, and the inpatient bed is needed for other medically unstable patients. Requesting review would likely forfeit the residential slot and prolong use of scarce 1:1 staffing. She understands both plans and refuses transfer.

choice_1.choice: Sign the medical endorsement and place the transfer order to the residential program today.

choice_2.choice: Document that you do not medically endorse transfer and request immediate administrative/ethics review to keep her here.
